13621.meaning_1: caused to take this; persuaded to accept this
13621.comment:
openrouter: tngtech/deepseek-r1t2-chimera:free
In contextual sentence 'ko nu taṃ idamādapayi', this specifically refers to implanting an idea ('this' being an abstract suggestion) into someone's mind through persuasion.
13621.example_1: Who put this idea in your head:

47797.comment:
openrouter: tngtech/deepseek-r1t2-chimera:free
The contextual sentence sn5.6:3.2 illustrates the passive sense of experiencing inevitable suffering (dukkhāni) through birth.
47797.example_1: when you’re born you undergo sufferings—

55371.comment:
openrouter: tngtech/deepseek-r1t2-chimera:free
In contextual sentence, negative imperative rocaye (m.c. for rocayassu) shows prohibitive use meaning "should not approve". The +acc case matches jātiṃ (rebirth-acc).
55371.example_1: that’s why you shouldn’t approve of rebirth.

38490.comment:
openrouter: tngtech/deepseek-r1t2-chimera:free
In the contextual example, functions causatively with accusative object (maṃ) and locative complement (sacce) showing placement.
38490.example_1: he settled me in the truth.

15457.comment:
openrouter: tngtech/deepseek-r1t2-chimera:free
Named after the bhikkhunī Upacālā who converses with Māra in this text from the Bhikkhunīsaṃyutta.

16552.meaning_1: wanting rebirth; wishing to be reborn
16552.comment:
openrouter: tngtech/deepseek-r1t2-chimera:free
In the contextual SN5.7 reference, used in questioning a bhikkhunī about her desire for rebirth location, showing soteriological implications.
16552.example_1: “Nun, where do you want to be reborn?”

41558.comment:
openrouter: tngtech/deepseek-r1t2-chimera:free
Variant conjugation of paṇidahati √dhā root. Contextual sentence shows directive mental application with cittaṃ (acc) as object.
41558.example_1: Set your heart on such places,

21014.meaning_1: bound with bonds of sensual desire; imprisoned by the fetter of desire
21014.comment:
openrouter: tngtech/deepseek-r1t2-chimera:free
SN5.7 context metaphorically describes human beings as prisoners bound by craving (taṇhā), depicted as fetters (bandhana) from Mara.
21014.example_1: they’re bound with the bonds of sensuality;

42276.comment:
openrouter: tngtech/deepseek-r1t2-chimera:free
Contextually implies metaphorical "consumed by fire (of passion)" in SN5.7: sabbo loko padhūpito.

98.comment:
openrouter: tngtech/deepseek-r1t2-chimera:free
In the contextual sentence, describes an unwavering/unshakeable mental state or meditative object

6111.grammar: pp of pajjalati with neg. prefix a-
6111.meaning_1: not burning; not blazing; not on fire
6111.comment:
openrouter: tngtech/deepseek-r1t2-chimera:free
In SN 5.7 context, describes an unagitated/unburning state. Sanskrit pra √val shows semantic expansion from physical burning to metaphorical extinguishing of passions.

63300.meaning_1: Sīsupacālā's Sutta; the discourse concerning Sīsupacālā
63300.comment:
openrouter: tngtech/deepseek-r1t2-chimera:free
Named after the nun Sīsupacālā who features in this discourse on overcoming fear and attaining liberation (SN 5:8). The title preserves the bhikkhunī's name in compound form.

8934.comment:
openrouter: x-ai/grok-4.1-fast
Eighth sutta (SN 23.8) of the Rādha Saṃyuttaṃ, so named from its discussion of arahants in dialogue with Rādha.

63299.comment:
openrouter: x-ai/grok-4.1-fast
Name of a bhikkhunī (SN 5.8.1.2), one of three sisters (with Selā and Upacālā), approached by Māra while robed up in the morning for almsround. Lit. "child Pacālā"; sīsu = child (nt), not sīsa = head (despite related entries). Pacālā likely diminutive or related to Upacālā.
63299.sutta_1: atha kho sīsupacālā bhikkhunī pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā …pe…
63299.example_1: Then the nun Sīsupacālā robed up in the morning …

58782.meaning_1: exhaustion of all activity; destruction of every action
58782.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This compound means "the exhaustion or destruction of all kamma (action)". In the contextual sentence from SN 5.8:5.3, it refers to one who has attained the end of all deeds, indicating a state of liberation where no further kamma is accumulated. The term is significant in Buddhist soteriology, representing the ultimate goal of ending the cycle of kamma and rebirth.
58782.example_1: He has attained the end of all deeds,

65003.meaning_1: the Selā Sutta; a discourse named after the laywoman Selā
65003.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
Selāsutta is the name of a discourse in the Bhikkhunī Saṃyutta (Saṃyutta Nikāya 5) named after the laywoman Selā. It is a kammadhāraya compound meaning "Selā's discourse" or "the sutta of Selā". The Sanskrit equivalent would be śailā sūtra. This sutta is part of the collection of discourses related to bhikkhunīs (nuns) in the Saṃyutta Nikāya.

23260.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
kvanu is an interrogative adverb meaning "where?" formed by the combination of the interrogative particle kva and the enclitic nu. In the context of sn5.9:2.2, it is used to question the location or existence of the maker of something, reflecting a contemplative or philosophical inquiry. The nu particle adds emphasis or emotional tone to the question.

2438.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
Used in SN 5.9 to describe a puppet that is not self-made, emphasizing that the body is not self-created but dependently originated. The term combines atta "self" with kata "made", forming a kammadhāraya compound meaning "self-made".

42864.meaning_1: made by another; done by someone else
42864.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 5.9:4.2, "nayidaṃ parakataṃ aghaṃ", the word parakata is used to deny that the suffering (agha) is caused by another being. It emphasizes that the misery is not externally imposed, but likely the result of one's own actions (kamma). This reflects a key Buddhist concept of personal responsibility for one's experiences.
42864.example_1: nor is this misery made by another.

71443.meaning_1: breaking up of the cause; dissolution of the condition; disintegration the pre-condition
71443.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term hetubhaṅga refers to the breaking up or dissolution of a cause or condition. In the contextual sentence from SN 5.9:4.4, "hetubhaṅgā nirujjhati", it indicates that something ceases when its underlying cause breaks up, reflecting the principle of dependent origination (paṭiccasamuppāda) in Buddhist philosophy. The compound is formed from hetu (cause) and bhaṅga (breaking, dissolution), and functions as a masculine noun in the kammadhāraya compound type.
71443.example_1: and ceases when the cause breaks up.

42039.meaning_1: fertility of the soil; soil's nutrients
42039.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The compound pathavīrasa literally means "essence of earth" or "taste of soil", used metaphorically in SN 5.9 to refer to the nutritive or fertile qualities of the earth that support life. The contextual sentence shows it as a basis or foundation upon which something relies, indicating the sustaining power of the soil.
42039.example_1: relying on both the soil’s nutrients

29839.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the context of SN5.9:5.4, "sinehañca tadūbhayaṃ" means "and moisture as well as both of those", referring to two previously mentioned elements. The word functions as an adjective meaning "both of those", formed by the combination of the pronoun "tad" (that) and "ubhaya" (both).

65702.meaning_1: the Vajirā discourse; a sutta named after bhikkhunī Vajirā
65702.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is the name of a sutta in the Bhikkhunīsaṃyutta (SN 5.10), attributed to the bhikkhunī Vajirā. The compound is a kammadhāraya where "vajirā" (the name of the nun) qualifies "sutta" (discourse), meaning "the discourse of Vajirā" or "Vajirā's sutta".

65701.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
Vajirā is a female name meaning "diamond", derived from the Pāḷi word vajira. In the contextual sentence from Saṃyutta Nikāya 5.10, she is identified as a bhikkhunī (nun) who goes on almsround in Sāvatthī. The name reflects the common Buddhist practice of giving spiritual names with symbolic meanings. The construction shows a taddhita derivation with the feminine suffix ā added to the base vajira.
65701.sutta_1: atha kho vajirā bhikkhunī pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
65701.example_1: Then the nun Vajirā robed up in the morning and, taking her bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

60904.meaning_1: conventional truth; worldly usage; common designation; relative truth as opposed to ultimate truth (paramatthasacca)
60904.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 5.10:5.4, "hoti sattoti sammuti", sammuti refers to the conventional or agreed-upon designation used to refer to a "sentient being". This reflects the Buddhist philosophical distinction between sammuti (conventional/relative truth) and paramatthasacca (ultimate truth). The term denotes the linguistic and conceptual conventions that societies agree upon to function, even though these designations may not reflect the ultimate nature of reality as understood in Buddhist analysis.
60904.example_1: ‘sentient being’ is the convention we use.

49020.meaning_1: the Brahmā Request Sutta; the discourse on Brahmā's invitation
49020.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is the first sutta of the Brahmā Saṃyutta (SN 6.1), where Brahmā Sahampati requests the Buddha to teach the Dhamma to the world. The compound means "the sutta concerning Brahmā's request/invitation", referring to Brahmā's entreaty for the Buddha to share his awakening with others.

24840.meaning_1: Discourse on Respect; the sutta concerning reverence
24840.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The gāravasutta is the second sutta of the Brahmā Saṃyutta (SN6.2), dealing with the theme of reverence or respect (gārava) shown by Brahmā to the Buddha. The compound is a kammadhāraya where "gārava" qualifies "sutta", meaning "the sutta that pertains to respect" or "the discourse on respect."

63212.meaning_1: more skilled in morality; more accomplished in virtue
63212.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This comparative adjective is used in SN 6.2:2.3 where the Buddha declares that he does not see any other ascetic or brahmin who is more accomplished than himself in ethical conduct (sīla). The term combines sīla (morality, virtue) with sampanna (accomplished, endowed) and the comparative suffix tara, forming a compound that literally means "more accomplished in virtue." It reflects the Buddha's supreme confidence in his moral perfection compared to other spiritual practitioners of his time.
63212.sutta_1: na kho panāhaṃ passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya attanā sīlasampannataraṃ aññaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā, yamahaṃ sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyaṃ.
63212.example_1: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who is more accomplished than myself in ethics, who I should honor and respect and rely on.

59669.meaning_1: more skilled in meditative composure; more accomplished in stability of mind
59669.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This comparative adjective describes someone who is more accomplished in samādhi (meditative composure) than another. In the contextual sentence from SN 6.2, the Buddha declares that he sees no other ascetic or brahmin who is more accomplished in immersion than himself, highlighting his supreme mastery of meditative concentration.
59669.sutta_1: na kho panāhaṃ passāmi sadevake loke …pe… attanā samādhisampannataraṃ aññaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā, yamahaṃ sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyaṃ.
59669.example_1: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin … who is more accomplished than myself in immersion …

40092.meaning_1: more full of wisdom; more accomplished in understanding
40092.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This comparative adjective is used in SN 6.2 to express the Buddha's assertion that no other ascetic or brahmin surpasses him in wisdom. The term combines paññā (wisdom) with sampanna (accomplished, full of) and the comparative suffix tara, literally meaning "more accomplished in wisdom". It functions as a kammadhāraya compound in its base form paññāsampanna, then takes the comparative ending tara.
40092.sutta_1: na kho panāhaṃ passāmi sadevake …pe… attanā paññāsampannataraṃ aññaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā, yamahaṃ sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyaṃ.
40092.example_1: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin … who is more accomplished than myself in wisdom …

68745.meaning_1: more skilled in liberation; more accomplished in emancipation
68745.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This comparative adjective is used in SN 6.2:5.2 where the Buddha declares that he does not see any other ascetic or brahmin who is more accomplished than himself in freedom (vimutti). The term combines "vimutti" (liberation) + "sampanna" (accomplished, endowed with) + "tara" (comparative suffix), forming a compound meaning "more accomplished in liberation." It reflects the Buddha's supreme confidence in his attainment of emancipation compared to other spiritual practitioners of his time.
68745.sutta_1: na kho panāhaṃ passāmi sadevake …pe… attanā vimuttisampannataraṃ aññaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā, yamahaṃ sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyaṃ.
68745.example_1: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin … who is more accomplished than myself in freedom …

68733.meaning_1: more accomplished in the knowledge and vision of liberation
68733.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This compound adjective in the comparative degree is used by the Buddha in SN 6.2 to assert his supreme attainment in the "knowledge and vision of liberation" (vimuttiñāṇadassana). The term combines vimutti (liberation), ñāṇa (knowledge), and dassana (vision/insight), all qualified by sampanna (accomplished/possessed of) and intensified by the comparative suffix -tara. The contextual sentence shows the Buddha declaring that no other ascetic or brahmin surpasses him in this specific spiritual accomplishment, highlighting the centrality of liberative knowledge in Buddhist soteriology.
68733.sutta_1: na kho panāhaṃ passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya attanā vimuttiñāṇadassanasampannataraṃ aññaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā, yamahaṃ sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyaṃ.
68733.example_1: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who is more accomplished than myself in the knowledge and vision of freedom, who I should honor and respect and rely on.

2399.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence vasavattino jātijaraṃ atītā, atīta is used as a past participle meaning "having passed beyond" or "overcome", referring to those who have transcended the cycle of rebirth and old age. The +acc case marking indicates it governs the accusative noun jātijaraṃ (rebirth and old age), showing what has been surpassed.
2399.example_1: having passed beyond rebirth and old age.

48973.meaning_1: the brahmadeva sutta; the discourse about the deity Brahmā
48973.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The brahmadevasuttaṃ is the third discourse in the Brahmā Saṃyutta (SN6.3), dealing with teachings related to the deity Brahmā. As a kammadhāraya compound, it means "the sutta concerning Brahmā" or "the discourse about the deity Brahmā". The compound is formed from brahmadeva ("the deity Brahmā") and sutta ("discourse, thread").

48972.meaning_1: name of a bhikkhu; name of an arahant
48972.family_set: names of monks; names of arahants
48972.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
Brahmadeva is a personal name meaning "God Brahmā" or "divine Brahmā", formed from the compound of brahma "Brahmā" (the Hindu creator god) and deva "god, deity". In the contextual sentence from SN 6.3, Brahmadeva is mentioned as the son of a brahmin lady who became a bhikkhu in the Buddha's dispensation. The name reflects the cultural context where brahmins and deities were part of the religious landscape, and the compound is a typical kammadhāraya (descriptive) compound where brahma qualifies deva.
48972.sutta_1: tena kho pana samayena aññatarissā brāhmaṇiyā brahmadevo nāma putto bhagavato santike agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti.
48972.example_1: Now at that time a certain brahmin lady had a son called Brahmadeva, who had gone forth from the lay life to homelessness in the presence of the Buddha.

56311.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 6.3, sakamātar refers to 'his own mother' as the bhikkhu approaches her residence for alms. The compound expresses possession and intimacy, emphasizing the personal relationship between the speaker and his mother. This is a kammadhāraya (descriptive) compound where 'saka' (own) qualifies 'mātar' (mother).
56311.sutta_1: sāvatthiyaṃ sapadānaṃ piṇḍāya caramāno yena sakamātu nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami.
56311.example_1: Wandering indiscriminately for almsfood in Sāvatthī, he approached his own mother’s home.

48986.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term brahmabhakkha literally means "food of Brahma" or "divine food". In the contextual sentence from SN 6.3:4.3, it is used metaphorically to contrast the pure, spiritual sustenance appropriate for a divinity with the coarse, material food being offered. The compound is formed with brahma (god, divine) in the second case (dutiyā) governing bhakkha (food, eating), indicating the type of food that is suitable for or belonging to a divine being.
48986.example_1: But the Divinity doesn’t eat that kind of food.

38092.meaning_1: free from attachment; free from grasping
38092.construction:
nir + upa + √dhā + i + ka
nirūpadhi + ka
38092.example_1: free of attachments, has surpassed the gods.

2164.meaning_1: gone beyond the gods; surpassed the divine beings; attained more than the gods
2164.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The compound atidevapatta is used in SN 6.3 to describe one who has transcended even the divine realm, indicating a state of liberation beyond all conditioned existence, including the heavenly realms. The term emphasizes the Buddhist concept that nibbāna is superior to any heavenly rebirth.
2164.example_1: free of attachments, has surpassed the gods.

3509.meaning_1: not nurturing another; (comm) not supporting another state of existence
3509.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word anaññaposī describes a mendicant who owns nothing and provides for no other, emphasizing complete non-attachment and independence from supporting or nurturing other beings or future states of existence. The compound literally means "not another-nurturing," reflecting the ideal of renunciation in early Buddhist monastic life.
3509.example_1: Owning nothing, providing for no other, <j>a mendicant

46959.meaning_1: before; in front; in the future
46959.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 6.3:7.1, "na tassa pacchā na puratthamatthi", puratthaṃ is used to mean "before" in a temporal sense, contrasting with "pacchā" (after). The phrase indicates that the enlightened being has no temporal sequence or linear time—no past ("puratthaṃ") and no future ("pacchā"). The form puratthaṃ is the accusative singular of purattha, which functions as an indeclinable adverb meaning "before" or "in front". It is derived from the root pura "forward, before" with the suffix -ttha, and takes the accusative ending -aṃ.
46959.example_1: He has no before and after,

36798.meaning_1: who has renounced violence; who has laid down the stick
36798.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term nikkhittadaṇḍa describes one who has放下 the rod or stick, symbolizing the renunciation of violence and harm toward all beings, as seen in the context of SN 6.3 where the Buddha declares he has laid down the rod for all creatures, firm and frail, indicating complete non-violence.
36798.example_1: he has laid down the rod <j>for all creatures firm and frail.

16104.meaning_1: with a calm mind; with a peaceful heart
16104.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The compound upasantacitta describes a mental state of tranquility and peace. In the contextual sentence from SN 6.3, it characterizes someone who has left the crowd with a peaceful mind, suggesting emotional serenity and mental composure. The first member upasanta is a past participle meaning "calmed, pacified, tranquil" and combines with citta "mind, heart" to form a bahubbīhi compound meaning "one whose mind is calm" or "having a calm mind".
16104.example_1: With peaceful mind, he has left the crowd,

87656.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 6.3:10.2, patiṭṭhapesi is used in the sense of presenting or offering a religious donation (dakkhiṇa) to someone worthy (dakkhiṇeyya). This reflects the causative meaning of the root verb patiṭṭhapeti: to cause something to stand, to set up, to establish, or to place before someone. The aorist form indicates a completed action in the past: "she set/placed/presented."
87656.example_1: she presented her religious donation <j>to one who is worthy of it.

47854.meaning_1: the Baka Brahma discourse; the sutta concerning Baka the Brahma deity
47854.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is SN 6.4, a discourse in the Brahma Saṃyutta where the Buddha encounters Baka the Brahma deity who believes his realm is permanent. The sutta demonstrates the impermanent nature of even the highest deva realms.
